header.name: chaos/preprocessor/algorithm/transform.h
header.author: Paul Mensonides
header.overview: The header defines an algorithm that transforms the elements of a with a user-specified operation.

macro.abstract: The macro transforms each element of its second argument with the operation specified by its first argument.

param.para:
The operation used to transform each element of g. This operation must be either a or a macro name that refers to a macro with a signature compatible with the following pseudo-signature:
op(s, elem†)

† If the type of g is non-variadic, elem must be ... or the number of parameters that corresponds to the number of sub-elements in each element of g. Otherwise, elem must be ... or a single parameter.

The operation used to transform each element of g. This operation must be either a or a macro name that refers to a macro with a signature compatible with the following pseudo-signature:
op(s, elem†, data‡)
† If the type of g is non-variadic, elem must be the number of parameters that corresponds to the number of sub-elements in each element of g. Otherwise, elem must be a single parameter.
‡ The data pseudo-parameter must be either ... or the number of parameters that corresponds to the number of arguments in the auxiliary data, __VA_ARGS__.

macro.para: The macro itself expands to a in terms of (s). This , when invoked by , expands to a of the same type as g that contains the transformed elements of g.

The operation is invoked with the current (s), a particular element (elem), and, if it exists, the auxiliary data (data or __VA_ARGS__). This invocation must expand to an element that replaces the element for which it is invoked or a in terms of (s) that expands to such an element. Expansion to a allows the operation to recurse on itself if necessary.

In C99, it is possible to omit the auxiliary data argument altogether. This is different than passing "nothing" as the auxiliary data.
#define D () (a, b, c)
( (OP, D,) // #1 (OP, D) // #2 )
The first line passes "nothing" as the auxiliary data, which causes OP to be invoked as (e.g.)... OP(s, a,) The second line omits the auxiliary data, which causes OP to be invoked as (e.g.)... OP(s, a) The fundamental difference is that, in the first line, the auxiliary data is empty (which might have a valid meaning as data), but, in the second line, there is no auxiliary data. Hence, the algorithm is overloaded on a .
Invocations of the operation are trampolined such that each invocation is invoked with (s), where s is the original at the beginning of the algorithm (i.e. ()). This maximizes the utility of the .

Ignoring the complexity of op (which is invoked once for each element in g), the running time of can be described in terms of the number of required to complete the algorithm. The asymptotic upper and lower bounds are Θ(n+1), where n is the number of elements in g.
